metadata.case_name: Raghuvanshi Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: The assessee Company's issued and subscribed capital was Rs. 10,00,000 divided into 10,000 shares of Rs. 100 each.
Prior to November 14, 1941, Maganlal Parbhudas held 6,344 shares and gifted 1,000 shares each to his five sons: Ravindra, Surendra, Bipinchandra, Hareshchandra and Krishnakumar.
Account year: April 1, 1942 to March 31, 1943; assessment year 1943-44. Dividend declared at AGM on December 17, 1943, less than required under s. 23A.

During accounting period, eight Directors held total 4,695 shares: Shri Maganlal Parbhudas (1,344), Ravindra Maganlal (1,168), Surendra Maganlal (1,100), Amritlal Chunilal jointly with Babulal Chunilal (833), Babulal Chunilal (100), Bhagwandas Harakchand (50), Haridas Purshottam (50), Sir Chunilal B. Mehta jointly with Lady Tapibai Chunilal (50).
Relatives of Directors held 4,754 shares: Shrimati Kantabai Maganlal (771), Bipinchandra Maganlal (1,000), Hareshchandra Maganlal (1,000), Krishnakumar Maganlal (1,000), others (total specified).
Remaining 551 shares held by members of the public unconnected with Directors.

Before March 1942, Managing Agents were Messrs. Ravindra Maganlal and Bros. (Maganlal sole proprietor). On March 7, 1942, appointed Ravindra Maganlal Co. Ltd. as Managing Agents for 20 years; its capital Rs. 5,000 subscribed equally by five sons.
Directors included Maganlal Parbhudas, Ravindra Maganlal, Surendra Maganlal. Ravindra, Surendra, Bipinchandra were Directors of Managing Company.
Income-tax Officer applied s. 23A holding company not one in which public substantially interested; confirmed by AAC and Tribunal.
Tribunal refused to state case under s. 66(1); Bombay High Court under s. 66(2) called for statement on question of s. 23A applicability.
High Court on March 10, 1953 directed Tribunal for supplementary statement, liberty for further evidence. On September 1, 1955, re-framed question and answered against assessee.
Tribunal found Directors, particularly three sons, under de facto control of Maganlal Parbhudas. Shares freely transferable.
High Court held evidence supported Tribunal's finding of de facto control by Maganlal over three sons.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the provisions of s. 23A of the Indian Income-tax Act, XI of 1922, are applicable to the petitioners?

Whether the shares held by Bipinchandra, Harishchandra and Krishnakumar can be considered to be shares held by members of the public within the meaning of the explanation to the third proviso to Section 23A?
Whether shares held by Directors must always be regarded as not held by the public.

Meaning of 'a company shall be deemed to be a company in which the public are substantially interested, if its shares carrying not less than twenty-five per cent. of the voting power have been allotted unconditionally to, or acquired unconditionally by, and are at the end of the previous year beneficially held by the public.'

petitioner_arguments.text: Test that shares held by Directors are not shares in which public substantially interested is incorrect; authorities proceeded on wrong assumption, failed to apply proper test in Explanation.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Explanation to third proviso to s. 23A

petitioner_arguments.text: 551 shares held by public; to avoid s. 23A, public need hold not less than 25% (2,500 shares). Even excluding Directors' 4,695, if sons' shares count as public, threshold met.

respondent_arguments.text: Shares held by persons interested in Managing Company under control of Directors; relatives mere nominees, voting power controlled by Directors; public not substantially interested.
Directors exercise de facto control over shareholders, particularly Maganlal over three sons.

court_reasoning.text: Essence of Explanation lies in words 'unconditionally' and 'beneficially'; no person holding not for own benefit but another's, not exercising voting power freely, belongs to 'public'. 'Public' contradistinguished from group acting in unison with block >75% voting power.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Percentage shows minimum; key is unconditional, beneficial holding.

court_reasoning.text: Directors' shares not automatically excluded from public; shareholders who are Directors do not cease to be public unless acting in concert as block.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mere position as Director not decisive.

court_reasoning.text: Relationship not decisive unless control of voting power proved. High Court erred in assuming Directors stand outside public.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Test is de facto control by group/block.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal finding: shares of Bipinchandra etc. (3,000) under control of father Maganlal (1,344), total 4,344; but does not dispose if >75% not beneficially held by public.

holdings.text: Directors cannot by reason of being Directors be said not to be members of the public.
Company deemed public substantially interested if >=25% voting power shares allotted/acquired unconditionally and beneficially held by public (not controlled by group/block).
High Court judgment erroneous; set aside and remand to decide original question on s. 23A applicability, may call supplemental statement.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sardar Baldev Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Delhi and Ajmer
precedents_cited.relevance: Section applies to company where >=75% voting power with group allied in interest, controlled by group.

precedents_cited.case_name: Tatem Steam Navigation Co., Ltd. v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents_cited.relevance: Niece's shares not excluded from public merely due to relationship; mere relationship not decisive unless control proved.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. H. Bjordal
precedents_cited.relevance: Shareholders who are Directors do not cease to be public; provision in pari materia with s. 23A.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jubilee Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Bombay HC view possibly erroneous per Privy Council; test is control by individual/group as block.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: s. 23A applied to undistributed profits if public not substantially interested (>=25% shares unconditionally/beneficially held by public); Tribunal/High Court references under s. 66.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgments of March 10, 1953 and September 1, 1955 set aside. High Court directed to decide original question on s. 23A applicability, may call supplemental statement from Tribunal if necessary.
outcome.relief_granted: Remand to High Court for fresh decision
outcome.costs: Respondents to bear costs of appeal

key_quotes.text: 'The essence of the Explanation lies not in the percentage which only shows the limit of the minimum holding by the public, but lies in the words unconditionally and beneficially.'
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Directors cannot, by reason of being Directors, be said not to be members of the public.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects automatic exclusion of Directors' shares from public

key_quotes.text: 'Public' is used in contradistinction to one or more persons who act in unison and among whom the voting power constitutes a block.
key_quotes.speaker: court
